The surface resembles a graveyard but with additional statues, fountains, walls, and tomb like structures that are actually dwellings and gates to the subterranean areas.

Terrain types are marked on the map according to players’ preference. Some terrain types will be referenced by cards but terrain types comprise:  Clear (Paths, Roads), Graves, Fountain, Wall (and Gates), Trees, Tomb and Statue.

Each player has a unique “army” list comprising 16 units of differing strengths (hit points), with differing characteristics.
Each player has a unique deck of cards of four different types (Attack, Defence, Move, Special)

To set up the decks are shuffled separately and units are placed in the back three rows of the player’s side of the board.

Naturals go first with players taking turns.  Each turn has 3 Phases: 
1. Draw Phase
-  Draw 3 cards and place them in your hand. 
2. Action Phase
-  Play cards (no limit). 
-  Play a Move card to move a unit the indicated (range) number of spaces. 
-  Use an Attack card to attack a unit at the indicated distance (range) from the attacking unit. 
-  Your opponent may use a Defence card to negate an Attack card.  
-  An attack card that is not negated causes the target to lose 1 Hit. Use tokens to keep track of Damage (lost hits) sustained by units.  Any Unit reduced to zero Hits is killed. 
3. End Phase
Max hand size is 7 cards.  Discard excess cards.

The first side to lose 10 or more units will break and flee.

Name: Nutcracker Skirmish
Description:
A 2-player skirmish game with a Nutcracker Theme.  One player is the Nutcracker and the toy soldiers, the other player is the Mice.

An 8x8 Grid is used as a board.  The “battlefield” is the living room floor at Christmas time.  There are two terrain types – clear or obstacles (boxes, christmas tree, furniture).  Obstacles block all movement and attacks.  Terrain is laid down at the players’ discretion.

Players share a common deck of cards.  Card are of four types: Attack (A), Defence (D), Movement (M), Special (S)

Each side gets a unique set of 16 units that can be moved around on the board. Units have different movement allowances and strengths (hit points).  One unit on each side is designated the Leader.  Units cannot stack but friendly units may move through each other.

To set up each player places his units in any of his 3 last rows.

Players take turns. 
Each turn has 3 Phases. 
1.  Presents Phase
-   Draw 3 cards from the deck and place them in your hand. 
2.  Action Phase
-   Play cards from your hand. 
-   Use Move cards to move one of your units up to the indicated number of spaces. Your opponent may use certain special cards to negate a Move. 
-   Use Attack cards to have a unit attack a target unit at the exact range indicated by the card and do 1 point of damage to the target (when hits are reduced to 0 the unit is destroyed). Your opponent may use Defence cards to reduce hits caused by an Attack.   
3. End Phase
Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.

The game is won when a player destroys his opponent’s leader (Nutcracker or Mouse King).  The last (killing) hit on a leader unit may only be made by the opposing leader unit.

Name: Boss Monster: Get Over Here! Promo Card
Description:
Promo Spell Card from Game Night Kit #2 from Brotherwise Games.

Card Text:

Get Over Here!
Choose a Hero in your dungeon. It skips the next Room it would enter. Deal 3 damage to that Hero.
OR
Choose an Epic Hero at the entrance to your dungeon. It skips the first four Rooms of your dungeon. Deal 10 damage to that Hero.

Name: Sumrun
Description: Horse racing game that comes with 5 metal horses in different colors. It uses roll & move mechanics, he who crosses the line first wins the game.

Name: Smelly Seth
Description:
Description from the designer:

What is Smelly Seth?
Smelly Seth is a fast paced and easy to learn card game. Your goal is to get the other players to “+11 Smell” and knock them out of the game. It’s great for warming up gaming night or at your local watering hole.

How many friends can I play with and how long is an average game?
You can play with 2-4 people, but 3-4 is best. An average game lasts between 15-20 minutes.

How do I play?
Every player starts with 3 cards. Each turn you will draw a card and then play  a card.  There are 3 types of cards: smell, clean and action. Smell cards can only be played on your opponents and clean cards on yourself. Action cards provide a fun turn of events in your favor!

Name: SPARKUP
Description:
Sparkup is a card game for 1-10 players that turns everyday people into entrepreneurs. Get inspired with new ideas. Pitch your invention. Vote for your favorite. From outrageous to ingenious, ignite the future.

Sparkup can be played as a party game for many people or as more of a brain game for 1-2 players. The game not only entertains but also can inspire those who play to come up with great ideas. It's game that goes beyond the game itself.

In just 20-30 minutes, players get the chance to become inventors and entrepreneurs as they are guided through an idea generation phase where they come up with a new idea. The entire game plays in 5 phases through a series of "minute to win it" challenges. This keeps everyone engaged and creating at the same time. When the time's up, each team takes turns pitching their ideas to the group. We're always amazed at what incredible things people can come up with given a little spark and a time limit. Next, each team secretly votes for the idea they like best. In the end, votes are revealed and one team is declared winner.

-- dscription from the designer:

Name: Aristotle's School
Description:
Players are students (Junior Members) of Aristotle’s school in Athens Circa 334 - 322 BC.  Players move about the Lyceum (Gymnasium and surrounding grounds) to acquire knowledge in a variety of categories and subjects.

The board is composed of 27 tiles, called Lyceum Tiles.  The tiles are organised into a circular track in a random order.

Players share a common deck. When a card is played, immediately gain its reward and then discard the card.  When the deck runs out the first time shuffle the discard and draw from it.

Players share a set of action tokens.  There are 7 types of tokens: Material Cause, Efficient Cause, Formal Cause, Final Cause, Potentiality, Actuality and Aristotle.  Actions tokens are used during the game for additional movement, gaining points in various categories, affecting die rolls etc.

There are 6 Categories: Philosophy, Logic, Life Science, Physical Science, Humanities and Arts.  Each Category is further divided into 6 Subjects.  During play points are earned in individual subjects, however for final end of game scoring, it is the total points earned by subjects within a category that count. Every time you gain a point in a Subject, you also get a corresponding Action Token according to the subjects tables.

Players take turns with each turn consisting of 3 phases:

1.  Aristotle Phase

     Aristotle starts the Game in Aristotle’s Library and moves in a clockwise direction 2D6 spaces. 
     Whenever he lands on a space containing one or more students, they each get 1 point in one random subject (first roll a random category, then a random subject) 
     If he lands in a space containing no students, the top card of the deck is placed onto that tile.  The first student to land there gets that card, as well as the tile’s regular offering. 
     If you land on Aristotle, you gain 1 Cause Token of any type.  
     If on your move you pass over Aristotle you gain 1 Aristotle Token. 


2.  Move Phase

     Move your Pawn forward (clockwise around the track) one or two spaces OR you may move forward 1D10 spaces. 
     You may spend an Action Token to alter your movement. 
     When you land on 1 or more opponents pawns, you may steal 1 Token from any one of them. 


3.  Learning 

     Follow the instructions on the tile you have just moved to.  This will usually earn you 1 card or some Action Tokens or 1 point in one specific Subject or a choice on a list, or a roll on a table. 


Scores are tracked using paper and pencil.

The game ends when players have gone through the deck twice.  
The player with the highest score in the most categories is the winner.

Name: Aquaman
Description:
A card game for 2-4 players with an Aquaman Theme.

Players share a common deck of 8 suites:  Aquaman (A), Companion (C), Sea Creature (X), Plot (P), Foe (F), Power (O), Strangeness (S) and Location (L).  Each suite comprises 16 cards ranked from 1 to 16.

The board is an 8x8 grid. Each square must be big enough to easily hold 1 card.  1 card is randomly dealt face up to each space on the board. Each player places their pawn on a different corner space (each pawn represents a different manifestation of Aquaman).

Each player draws 3 cards to start.

Players take turns with each turn comprising five phases:

1. Power Phase
-  If you have at least 5 cards in your hand, you may discard 1 card from your hand to activate its special ability: 
-  Aquaman: Draw 2 cards from the deck & put them in your hand. If the sum of the ranks of the 2 cards is less than the rank of the Aquaman card, draw and keep a third card. 
-  Companion: Look at the next 4 cards in the deck. Keep one and 
discard the other 3. The one you keep must be of a lower rank than the Companion Card. 
-  Sea Creature: Take the top card of discard and put it in your hand. 
It must be of a lower rank than the Sea Creature card. 
-  Plot: You may move your pawn to any target, non-occupied space this turn in Swim phase (do not bother rolling the dice). The card in the target space must be of a lower Rank than the Plot card. 
-  Foe: Target opponent who is adjacent to you must reveal one random card from his hand; if it is lower in rank than the Foe card it is discarded.  
-  Power: Discard X cards and draw X replacement cards. The cards you discard may not be of a higher Rank than the Power card. 
-  Strangeness: Put 1 target adjacent card on the board in your hand. It must be of a lower rank than the Strangeness card. Immediately draw a card to replace it with on the Board.   
-  Location: Look at the next X cards in the deck where X = the rank of the Location card.

2.  Swim Phase

     Roll two dice. Move your pawn on the board orthogonally first the distance of one of the dice, and then the distance of the other. For example, you roll a 2 and a 5.  You decide to first move him to your left 5 spaces and then forward 2 spaces. 


3.  Action Phase

     If you land on a space not occupied by another pawn, take the card there and put it in your hand. Immediately replace the card you took with the top card of the deck. 
     If the space is occupied by another player’s pawn, there will be a fight: Both players reveal 1 card from their hand. High card wins. If tied, players reveal a second card. Discard all revealed cards. The winner gets to look at the loser’s hand and steal 1 card. 


4.  Mission Phase

     You may complete a Mission.  To do this play (discard) 8 cards from your hand, one from each of the eight suites.  


5.  Rest Phase

     Max hand size is 10 cards. Discard excess cards. 


The first player to complete 3 Missions is the winner.

Name: Apotheosis of Technology
Description:
A card game for 2-4+ players with the theme of Technological Advancements of the next 1000 Years.

Players share a common set of Victory Tokens (VT), Research Tokens (RT) and Energy Tokens (ET).

There are 10 small decks with each deck representing a century. Each card represents a new technology, event, discovery, or social change. When played, cards will cause players to gain VT, RT, ET, steal cards from other players, increase hand size etc.

Each player starts with 10 VT and is dealt 2 cards from the 21st Century Deck. (Disaster cards are discarded and redrawn).

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases.

1.  Resource Phase

     Gain 1 Research Token and 1 Energy Token


2.  Discovery Phase

     Draw 1 card from the current deck (the oldest deck that still has at least 1 card in it). If the deck runs out go on to the next deck.
     Pay 5 RT to draw an extra card. 
     Whenever you draw a disaster card reveal and play it immediately. Resolve the disaster and continue drawing. When Disaster cards are played, they are removed from the game. 
     Every player starts with a pick ability of 1. For every increase in pick ability (as a result of card play), you may, when drawing a card, draw an extra card, pick 1 of your choice and place the others back on the top of the deck. (Disasters don't count against your pick limit). 


3.  Implementation Phase

     Play 1 card from your hand to the table. 
     Pay 5 ET to play an extra card. 


4.  Progress Phase

     Max hand size is 4 cards. Discard excess cards. (If a card is discarded it goes to the bottom of its deck). 


The game ends when the Apotheosis of Technology card (in the 30th century deck) is revealed.  The player with the most Victory Tokens at the end of the game wins.

Name: Minister Most Sinister
Description:
Description from the publisher:

Defeat the blue suit and save Canada from electile dysfunction in this cooperative game guaranteed to raise the best-glued toupees.

In Minister Most Sinister, you play as one of the four challengers vying to topple the toupee. Candidates race around the campaign trail trying to collect sets of cards that ridicule Stevie's shortcomings on Business, Science, Security and Popularity issues. Will you work together to take back some of the Sinister-engineered disadvantages and give your fellow candidates enough resources to challenge and defeat Stevie in time, or will individual greed allow the Worst-Past-the-Post system to squeeze out another Sinister win?

Have no fear: unlike the longest election in over a hundred years, Minister Most Sinister doesn't take 78 days and hundreds of millions of dollars to play. This fast-paced game plays in under 20 minutes with 2 to 4 players. And with 18 different Election Rules, each new game will test your campaigning abilities against the Man in the Blue Suit's devious schemes.

Name: Lawless Empire: Lawless Invasion
Description: Lawless Invasion is the expansion set that will be bundled together with the base set in the Kickstarter campaign.  The plot unfolds against the backdrop of an invasion of the city of Scarpizo by a new Yakuza clan that has the intention of taking over all of Scarpizo's vices.  Lawless Invasion features 8 new soldati and 8 new scheme cards to increase the re-playability of the base set.  In addition, it comes together with an infusion of Japanese artwork to immerse gamers in a gang war of epic proportion between the Yakuza and the Mafia.
